questions.text: A 25-yr old female has been diagnosed to be suffering from tuberculosis categorized as drug sensitive previously treated. The new treatment regimen recommended is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 2(HRZE) + 4(HRE) The recommended treatment regimen for drug-sensitive, previously treated tuberculosis (TB) follows the guidelines set by the National Tuberculosis Elimination Program (NTEP) in India and WHO recommendations. HRZE stands for Isoniazid (H), Rifampicin (R), Pyrazinamide (Z), and Ethambutol (E). HRE stands for Isoniazid (H), Rifampicin (R), and Ethambutol (E). The standard regimen for previously treated drug-sensitive TB is: 2 months of intensive phase (HRZE) + 4 months of continuation phase (HRE). This regimen is effective, short-course, and helps prevent the development of resistance. Incorrect Options: (B) 2 (HRSZE) + 1 (HRZE) + 5 (HRE) (Incorrect): This regimen includes Streptomycin (S), which is not recommended for drug-sensitive TB anymore. Also, the continuation phase should be 4 months, not 5 months. (C) 3 (HRZE) + (HRZE) + 2 (HRE) + 4 (HR) (Incorrect): This regimen overextends the intensive phase, which is not required for drug-sensitive TB. The correct protocol is 2 months of HRZE, not 3 months. The continuation phase should include HRE, but this option also includes HR for 4 months, which is not a standard recommendation. (D) 3(HRSZE) + 1 (HRZE) + 6(HRE) (Incorrect): This regimen again includes Streptomycin (S), which is not part of the current standard treatment for drug-sensitive TB. The intensive phase is too long (3 months instead of 2 months), which is unnecessary for drug-sensitive TB. The continuation phase is 6 months instead of 4 months, which is longer than the recommended regimen.

questions.text: According to RNTCP, sputum sample for testing of TB are packed in two containers which are labelled as :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) A & B Under the Revised National Tuberculosis Control Program (RNTCP), now integrated into the National Tuberculosis Elimination Program (NTEP), sputum samples for diagnosis of pulmonary tuberculosis are collected and packed in two separate sterile, leak-proof containers, labeled as A and B. The two-sample method is used to increase the detection rate of Mycobacterium tuberculosis and ensure accurate diagnosis. Sample A: Collected as an on-the-spot sample when the patient first visits the health center. Sample B: An early morning sample, collected the next day to improve diagnostic accuracy. This labeling system helps in proper identification, transport, and tracking of the samples in the laboratory. Incorrect Options: (A) Alpha & Beta (Incorrect): The RNTCP does not use Greek letters for labeling sputum samples. Standard practice is to label the containers as A and B to maintain uniformity across TB testing centers. (B) 1 & 2 (Incorrect): While numbering is a logical approach, RNTCP guidelines specifically use the labels A and B for clarity and consistency. Using numbers instead of letters could lead to misidentification in some settings. (D) Y & Z (Incorrect): The labels Y and Z are not used under the RNTCP/NTEP system. The standardized labeling system ensures consistency across all TB testing centers.

choices.text: He is declared a sputum smear + ve case: started with DOTS drug sensitive new case
He is declared a sputum smear -ve case
He will undergo sputum smear examinations after 12 months again

questions.text: A 26 years old male has symptom suggestive of TB. At DOTS clinic, he underwent 2 sputum examination. Only one of the sputum smears turns out to be positive. Next step of management will be:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) He is declared a sputum smear-positive case and started with DOTS drug-sensitive new case. According to the Revised National Tuberculosis Control Program (RNTCP), now under National Tuberculosis Elimination Program (NTEP), the diagnosis of pulmonary tuberculosis (TB) is based on sputum smear microscopy results. If a patient presents with symptoms suggestive of TB, at least two sputum samples (one on-the-spot and one early morning) are tested for Acid-Fast Bacilli (AFB). If one out of two sputum smears is positive, the patient is considered a sputum smear-positive case and immediately started on treatment under the DOTS (Directly Observed Treatment, Short-Course) regimen for drug-sensitive TB. Since TB is a public health concern, early diagnosis and treatment initiation are crucial to prevent further transmission. Incorrect Options: (B) He is declared a sputum smear-negative case (Incorrect): A sputum smear-negative case is one where both sputum samples are negative, but the patient has persistent symptoms. In this case, since one sample is positive, he is classified as sputum smear-positive, and not smear-negative. (C) He will undergo sputum smear examinations after 12 months again (Incorrect): Delaying diagnosis and treatment for 12 months would lead to disease progression and increased transmission. Instead, TB treatment should be initiated immediately upon confirmation of smear-positive status. (D) Drug-resistant TB (Incorrect): Drug-resistant TB (MDR-TB or XDR-TB) is diagnosed based on GeneXpert, Line Probe Assay (LPA), or Culture & Drug Sensitivity Testing (DST). A single positive sputum smear does not confirm drug resistance. The patient is classified as having drug-sensitive TB unless further testing indicates resistance.

questions.text: Schedule for sputum examination for drug sensitive new patients is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 2 & 6 months Under the Revised National Tuberculosis Control Program (RNTCP), now integrated into the National Tuberculosis Elimination Program (NTEP), the sputum examination schedule for drug-sensitive new pulmonary TB patients is conducted at 2 months (end of intensive phase) and 6 months (end of treatment). At 2 months (End of Intensive Phase - IP): A sputum smear examination is done to assess response to treatment. If the sputum is still positive, an extended intensive phase may be considered. At 6 months (End of Continuation Phase - CP): A final sputum examination is conducted to confirm treatment completion and cure. If the patient remains positive, further evaluation for drug resistance (MDR-TB/XDR-TB) is required. This schedule ensures that treatment is monitored effectively and that the patient is responding well to anti-TB therapy. Incorrect Options: (A) 2, 3, and 5 months (Incorrect): The standard protocol does not include sputum testing at 3 and 5 months for drug-sensitive TB. The key check points are 2 months and 6 months. (C) 1, 3, and 5 months (Incorrect): Sputum testing at 1 month is unnecessary, as it does not significantly change management. Testing at 3 and 5 months is also not part of the standard protocol for new drug-sensitive TB cases. (D) 2, 5, and 7 months (Incorrect): Sputum testing at 5 and 7 months is not standard practice for monitoring new drug-sensitive TB cases. Testing at 6 months (not 7 months) is the correct approach to confirm cure and treatment completion.

questions.text: Best indicator trend of TB affected by current control measures is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Annual Risk of TB Infection (ARTI)/ Tuberculin Conversion Index (TCI): Definition: Proportion of population which will be primarily infected with TB in course of 1 year Importance: - Indicates incidence of TB infection - Best indicator of trend of TB affected by current control measures - Most informative index of magnitude of TB problem - ARTI in India = 1- 2% - For every 1% rise of ARTI, there are 50 SS + ve cases/ lac population

questions.text: A adult male presented in OPD with complains of cough & fever for 3 weeks & sputum +ve. On probing it was found that he had already received RHZE for 2 weeks but had discontinued. How will you manage the patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) As drug-sensitive new case The patient is a new case of tuberculosis (TB) despite having received treatment for 2 weeks with RHZE (Rifampicin, Isoniazid, Pyrazinamide, and Ethambutol) but discontinued the treatment. According to RNTCP/NTEP guidelines, this patient would still be categorized as a new case because: New case: A patient who has not been previously treated for TB or has received treatment for less than 1 month. Since the patient discontinued treatment early, it is not considered a previously treated case, and he is still treated as a drug-sensitive new case. The patient is sputum positive, which indicates that he still has active tuberculosis, and he will be started on DOTS (Directly Observed Treatment, Short-Course) with the standard drug regimen for drug-sensitive TB. Incorrect Options: (B) As drug-sensitive previously treated (Incorrect): The patient is considered new because he has not completed the full 1-month treatment course. A previously treated case refers to someone who has received TB treatment for 1 month or more but has either been relapsed or experienced treatment failure. (C) As drug-resistant (Incorrect): There is no indication from the information provided that this patient has drug-resistant TB. The patient is receiving RHZE (which is for drug-sensitive TB), and there is no mention of drug resistance tests or signs of treatment failure. (D) Investigate again (Incorrect): While it is important to confirm the diagnosis, the patient has already been diagnosed as sputum-positive and is likely to have TB. Further investigation is not necessary unless there is suspicion of drug-resistant TB, but based on the information provided, the treatment should proceed as drug-sensitive TB.

choices.text: Report to PHC if new symptoms arise

questions.text: A person with tuberculosis on domiciliary treatment is expected to do all except::
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Use separate vessels A person with tuberculosis (TB) on domiciliary treatment is expected to follow certain practices to manage their condition and prevent transmission to others. These practices focus on safe handling of sputum, regular medication intake, and communication with healthcare providers. Dispose sputum safely: Sputum is the primary vehicle for TB transmission. The patient must dispose of sputum properly to prevent infecting others. This includes using a covered container and discarding it in a safe manner, such as through incineration or proper waste disposal systems. Collect drugs regularly: Adherence to the prescribed treatment regimen is crucial for the effective treatment of TB. The patient is expected to collect their medication from a healthcare facility, ensuring they continue the treatment without interruption. Report to PHC if new symptoms arise: If any new symptoms develop, such as worsening cough, fever, or side effects from the medication, the patient must report to the Primary Health Centre (PHC). This allows for early detection of complications or issues with treatment. Incorrect Options: (A) Dispose sputum safely (Correct): Proper disposal of sputum is essential to avoid the spread of TB. The patient should follow this practice to minimize the risk of infecting others in their household or community. (C) Collect drugs regularly (Correct): Regular drug collection ensures the patient adheres to their treatment regimen, which is critical for cure and preventing drug resistance. This practice is a standard requirement in the TB treatment process. (D) Report to PHC if new symptoms arise (Correct): Reporting to the PHC when new symptoms emerge helps the healthcare team monitor treatment effectiveness and address any complications, including potential drug side effects or treatment failure. Early intervention can prevent the progression of the disease.

choices.text: All children between 0-5 years of age on a single day irrespective of their previous immunization status :
Children in the age group 0-1 year only who have not been immunized
Children in the age group of 12-24 months only as the booster dose
All children between 0-5 years of age, wherever there is outbreak

questions.text: Pulse polio immunization is administration of OPV to :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) All children between 0-5 years of age on a single day irrespective of their previous immunization status Pulse Polio Immunization (PPI) is a key part of the global strategy to eradicate polio. It involves the administration of Oral Polio Vaccine (OPV) to all children under the age of 5 years, regardless of their previous immunization status. The goal is to boost immunity and prevent any missed cases of polio in the population. Pulse polio campaigns are carried out on specific days, targeting all children in this age group, even if they have already received the vaccine in the past. This approach helps ensure widespread immunity across all children and reduces the chances of the virus circulating in the community. Incorrect Options: (B) Children in the age group 0-1 year only who have not been immunized (Incorrect): Pulse polio is not limited to children aged 0-1 year or those who have not been immunized. It targets all children aged 0-5 years, regardless of prior vaccination status. Limiting it only to children in this age group would not provide sufficient protection to the broader population. (C) Children in the age group of 12-24 months only as the booster dose (Incorrect): Pulse polio immunization is not a booster dose for children aged 12-24 months. The objective is to administer OPV to all children under 5 years to ensure universal immunity, not just as a booster for a specific group. (D) All children between 0-5 years of age, wherever there is an outbreak (Incorrect): While it is crucial to provide pulse polio immunization during an outbreak, the program is not limited to outbreak situations. Pulse polio campaigns are conducted regularly, nationwide, to prevent polio transmission, not just in response to outbreaks.

choices.text: WHO recommends it for age less than 15 years
Two stool sample are collected per case
Non-polio AFP rate should be > 2 per 100000 among < 15 yrs old
Adequate stool specimens should be taken from 100% AFP

questions.text: All are true regarding AFP surveillance except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) It is in 90% cases AFP Surveillance AFP means that paralysis is of < 4 weeks onset & the affected limbs are flaccid, i.e. floppy or limp Target age group: 0- 15 years Non polio AFP rate in < 15 years: > 2/ 1 lac • AFP causes: • Acute paralytic polio • Transverse myelitis • Traumatic neuritis • GBS • Entero virus (71, 72) • Timeline for AFP Surveillance: • AFP case investigation: Done with in 2 days of notification • Ideally within 2 weeks of paralysis onset & at least 24 hours apart • Can be collected up to 2 months from the date of paralysis onset • Must re-visit every case of AFP 60 days after the onset of paralysis to confirm the presence or absence of residual paralysis • Stool sample: • 2 stool specimens are collected • 8 grams – each about the size of one adult thumb • Clean, dry, screw-capped container • No preservative • Reverse cold chain (red coloured vaccine carrier) at 2-8 degree • Target: > 80% (to maintain stool adequacy)

questions.text: In acute flaccid paralysis surveillance evaluation for residual paralysis should be done after:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 60 days In the context of Acute Flaccid Paralysis (AFP) surveillance, residual paralysis is assessed after 60 days to help determine whether the paralysis is due to polio or another cause. The 60-day evaluation is a standard protocol used to differentiate between polio and other causes of paralysis. After 60 days, if the patient still has residual paralysis, it is more likely to be due to a condition other than polio, such as a non-polio enterovirus. This assessment helps in ensuring that cases of polio are identified and monitored appropriately as part of the global effort to eradicate polio. Incorrect Options: (A) 30 days (Incorrect): A 30-day evaluation would be too early to determine if paralysis is residual or not. The assessment needs to be done after 60 days, as acute paralysis can sometimes improve within a month but may still leave lasting effects. Therefore, 30 days is not sufficient to establish whether paralysis is residual. (C) 90 days (Incorrect): While a 90-day evaluation could potentially show residual effects, the standard protocol is to perform the evaluation after 60 days, which is the established timeframe for the residual paralysis assessment in AFP surveillance. (D) 120 days (Incorrect): A 120-day evaluation is unnecessary and longer than required. The 60-day period is the standard used to determine if there is residual paralysis due to polio or another condition. Any evaluation at this stage would not provide additional clinical benefit in the context of polio surveillance.

choices.text: To confirm year of onset of illness

questions.text: Line listing of cases of Acute flaccid paralysis is done for all of the following reasons except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) To confirm year of onset of illness Line listing of cases of Acute Flaccid Paralysis (AFP) is an essential part of surveillance to ensure thorough monitoring and identification of polio cases. The purpose of line listing is to systematically document each case of AFP and track specific data points to ensure no cases are overlooked and to better understand trends in the disease's spread. The line listing is not used specifically for confirming the year of onset of illness, but rather for organizing and analyzing important epidemiological data. Incorrect Options: (A) To check for duplication (Correct): Line listing helps in identifying duplicate cases by comparing case details. This ensures accurate data collection and avoids the possibility of counting the same case more than once. This is a critical part of surveillance to maintain the integrity of the data. (B) To document high risk groups (Correct): One of the primary goals of line listing is to document high-risk groups affected by AFP. This helps in identifying populations that may require additional intervention or surveillance, such as those living in areas with poor healthcare access or communities with low vaccination coverage. (D) To identify high-risk population (Correct): Line listing is used to identify high-risk populations that may be more susceptible to developing AFP or polio. This could include children under five years, those in areas with lower immunization rates, or regions experiencing outbreaks. Understanding these groups helps tailor health interventions more effectively.

choices.text: Acute flaccid paralysis in a child <15 years of age
All cases of AFP should be reported irrespective of diagnosis within 6 months of onset
Two specimen collected within 14 days of paralysis

questions.text: All are true regarding Acute flaccid paralysis in national polio eradication programme, except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) All cases of AFP should be reported irrespective of diagnosis within 6 months of onset In the National Polio Eradication Programme, specific guidelines are followed for the surveillance of Acute Flaccid Paralysis (AFP) to help detect polio cases and ensure no cases go undiagnosed. However, the statement that all cases of AFP should be reported irrespective of diagnosis within 6 months of onset is incorrect. While it is critical to report all suspected AFP cases, the key focus is on reporting within a shorter timeframe, generally within 30 days of onset, not 6 months. After this period, the likelihood of identifying polio-related cases decreases significantly, and follow-up guidelines differ. Incorrect Options: (A) Acute flaccid paralysis in a child <15 years of age (Correct): The surveillance for Acute Flaccid Paralysis (AFP) specifically targets children under 15 years of age because polio primarily affects young children. This age group is the focus of active polio monitoring. (C) Two specimens collected within 14 days of paralysis (Correct): In the National Polio Eradication Programme, two stool specimens are collected from the patient within 14 days of paralysis onset for laboratory testing. This is necessary to confirm whether the paralysis is caused by polio and to help with effective surveillance. (D) 60 days follow-up examination (Correct): After the initial diagnosis, residual paralysis is examined 60 days after the onset. This follow-up helps to determine if the paralysis is likely due to polio or another cause. A prolonged paralysis could indicate polio infection if residual symptoms persist after 60 days.

questions.text: Data regarding recent trend of Immunization in community can be found by
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) DLHS (District Level Household Survey) The District Level Household Survey (DLHS) provides valuable data on health indicators, including immunization trends within specific communities. It collects detailed information from households at the district level and is especially useful for understanding recent trends in immunization coverage, maternal and child health, and other key health indicators. The DLHS is specifically designed to collect such community-level data, and it is regularly used for monitoring and assessing the effectiveness of health programs, including immunization campaigns. Incorrect Options: (A) Census data (Incorrect): While the Census provides detailed demographic data about the population (e.g., age, sex, and geographic distribution), it does not focus specifically on health indicators like immunization rates. Census data typically doesn’t track trends in health-related topics such as immunization. (B) Rural survey (Incorrect): Although a Rural Survey can provide insights into the health situation in rural areas, it is not the primary source for detailed, recent immunization data. Rural surveys may capture some health data but often do not provide the comprehensive immunization trends that DLHS does. (D) SRS (Incorrect): The Sample Registration System (SRS) primarily tracks birth and death rates, not specifically immunization data. While it plays a key role in demographic monitoring, it is not the best source for up-to-date trends in immunization coverage at the community level.

questions.text: Screening test used in ANC mothers under RMNCH+A at level of subcenter is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) HB (Hemoglobin) Under the RMNCH+A (Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn, Child Health + Adolescents) program, the screening of Hemoglobin (HB) levels in ANC (Antenatal Care) mothers is a key practice at the subcenter level. Screening for Hemoglobin helps in identifying anemia in pregnant women, which is a common condition that can lead to complications for both the mother and the baby, such as premature birth, low birth weight, and maternal mortality. Early detection and management of anemia through iron supplementation or other interventions are vital for improving maternal and fetal health outcomes. Incorrect Options: (B) Rh (Incorrect): Rh factor screening is important in some cases, especially in detecting Rh incompatibility (which can lead to hemolytic disease of the newborn), but it is not routinely performed as a primary screening test at the subcenter level. Rh testing is more often done in the context of specific risk factors or clinical indications. (C) TSH (Incorrect): Screening for Thyroid Stimulating Hormone (TSH) levels is important for identifying thyroid disorders like hypothyroidism during pregnancy, but it is typically done in higher health facilities (like PHCs, CHCs, or district hospitals) rather than at the subcenter level. (D) Urinary analysis for UTI (Incorrect): While urinary analysis for UTI (Urinary Tract Infection) may be performed during antenatal visits, it is not typically a primary screening test at the subcenter level. This test is usually conducted if the patient presents with symptoms or as part of a broader examination in higher-level care centers.

questions.text: A 15 day old newborn suffering from cough, sneezing and fever needs medical help. Mother has no money for transportation to the hospital. Which of the following national health programme can help the women?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) JSSK (Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram) The Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram (JSSK) is a national health program in India that ensures free transportation, medical care, and medications for pregnant women and newborns in public health facilities. In this case, the mother and the 15-day-old newborn can avail free transport to the hospital under JSSK, which provides free emergency medical services for both mother and child during and after delivery, including care for neonates with illnesses such as cough, sneezing, and fever. Incorrect Options: (A) F-IMNCI (Incorrect): F-IMNCI (Facility-based Integrated Management of Neonatal and Childhood Illness) focuses on improving the quality of care for newborns and children under 5 in health facilities. It doesn't directly provide transportation assistance or financial support, making it unsuitable in this situation where the mother needs help with transportation to the hospital. (C) NSSK (Incorrect): NSSK (National Sick Newborn Care Program) focuses on providing specialized care for sick newborns in health facilities, particularly at the district hospital level. While this program is important for newborn care, it does not offer financial assistance or transportation services for families who cannot afford them, which is the issue in this scenario. (D) IGMSY (Incorrect): IGMSY (Indira Gandhi Matritva Sahyog Yojana) provides cash incentives for pregnant women and lactating mothers for institutional deliveries and prenatal and postnatal care. However, it does not provide transportation or emergency medical services for sick newborns.

choices.text: There is one ASHA worker per 1000 population
ASHA is not a skilled birth attendant
Provides primary medical care for minor ailments

questions.text: About ASHA true is all except :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Provides primary medical care for minor ailments ASHA (Accredited Social Health Activist) workers are community health workers who play a crucial role in promoting health and delivering health-related services in rural and underserved areas. However, their responsibilities do not include providing primary medical care for minor ailments. ASHAs assist with tasks like promoting health education, increasing awareness, ensuring immunization, and mobilizing communities for maternal and child health. They are not trained to provide direct medical treatment for health conditions. Incorrect Options: (A) They are preferably female (Correct): ASHA workers are preferably female to ensure better community acceptance, especially in rural areas. Women are often more trusted to deliver health messages and assist with maternal and child health-related activities in their communities. (B) There is one ASHA worker per 800 population (Correct): The norm for the number of ASHAs in a community is one ASHA worker per 800 people. This ensures that there is sufficient coverage for health promotion activities and support in rural and urban areas. (C) ASHA is not a skilled birth attendant (Correct): While ASHA workers are involved in maternal health care, they are not skilled birth attendants. Skilled birth attendants are typically trained nurses or doctors who assist during delivery. ASHAs help by providing support and encouraging women to give birth in health facilities, but they do not perform medical procedures.

questions.text: Under NRHM, lowest level at which health action plan is prepared is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Village level Under the National Rural Health Mission (NRHM), the lowest level at which a health action plan is prepared is at the village level. This plan is developed to address the specific health needs of the local community. It is based on the assessment of health priorities and resources in the village, and it aligns with broader health objectives at the district, state, and national levels. This community-driven approach ensures that health services are tailored to the local population's needs. Incorrect Options: (A) State level (Incorrect): The state level plays a crucial role in the overall coordination and implementation of health policies and programs. However, the health action plan under NRHM is not developed at the state level but at more localized levels, like the village or district levels. (B) District level (Incorrect): While the district level also prepares health action plans and is important for coordination, the village level is the most localized and grassroots level at which health action plans are made in the NRHM. The district-level plans are often based on inputs from the village-level plans. (C) Sub centre level (Incorrect): Sub-centres are the first point of contact for rural health services, but health action plans are not specifically prepared at the sub-centre level. Rather, the village-level health plan, developed with inputs from the community and healthcare workers, feeds into broader health action strategies at higher levels.

questions.text: Resource persons for training of ASHA
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) ANM and Anganwadi Worker The Accredited Social Health Activist (ASHA) is a key component of India’s community health programs, particularly under the National Health Mission (NHM). ASHAs are trained by Auxiliary Nurse Midwives (ANMs) and Anganwadi Workers (AWWs), who serve as resource persons due to their experience in community health and maternal-child healthcare. ANMs provide technical knowledge related to maternal health, immunization, family planning, and disease prevention, while Anganwadi Workers (AWWs) focus on nutrition, early childhood care, and community mobilization. Since ASHAs work closely with both ANMs and AWWs at the village level, these two are best suited to train them in health education and service delivery. Incorrect options: A. Medical Officer & ANM While Medical Officers (MOs) play a role in overseeing healthcare services at the Primary Health Centre (PHC) level, they are not directly involved in the routine training of ASHAs. ANMs have a more direct role in training ASHAs at the community level, making ANM & AWW the correct choice. B. Medical Officer & Anganwadi Worker Medical Officers are responsible for higher-level supervision and treatment rather than the hands-on training of ASHAs. Anganwadi Workers, while involved in community nutrition and childcare, are not the sole trainers. Training ASHAs requires a combination of expertise in healthcare (ANMs) and community engagement (AWWs). D. Medical Officer Medical Officers provide guidance and supervision but do not conduct the practical, community-based training required for ASHAs. Their role is more focused on clinical services and policymaking rather than grassroots-level training.

questions.text: ASHA is recruited under :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) NRHM (National Rural Health Mission) The Accredited Social Health Activist (ASHA) is a key community health worker under the National Rural Health Mission (NRHM), which is a part of the broader National Health Mission (NHM). ASHAs are recruited to act as a bridge between the community and the healthcare system, promoting maternal and child health, immunization, family planning, and disease control at the village level. They are selected from the local community to ensure better outreach and trust. Incorrect options: B. National Urban Health Mission (NUHM) NUHM focuses on providing healthcare services in urban areas, but ASHAs were originally introduced under NRHM, which is specifically designed for rural healthcare. Although NUHM has its own community health workers, ASHAs are primarily recruited under NRHM. C. ICDS (Integrated Child Development Services) ICDS is a program under the Ministry of Women and Child Development that primarily deals with nutrition, child health, and preschool education through Anganwadi Workers (AWWs). ASHAs, however, work under the health ministry’s NRHM, not ICDS. D. Village Health System There is no separate scheme called the "Village Health System" under which ASHAs are recruited. ASHAs work within NRHM's framework, particularly through Village Health and Nutrition Days (VHNDs) to promote health awareness.

questions.text: Janani Suraksha Yojana includes:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Institutional deliveries The Janani Suraksha Yojana (JSY) is a maternity benefit program aimed at promoting institutional deliveries to reduce maternal and neonatal mortality. The scheme provides financial incentives to pregnant women for delivering in a health facility, ensuring that both the mother and newborn receive proper care during childbirth. The goal is to increase institutional deliveries and reduce the number of home births that are risky for both the mother and the baby. Incorrect Options: (A) Tetanus immunization (Incorrect): While tetanus immunization is an important aspect of maternal care, it is not the primary focus of the Janani Suraksha Yojana. The JSY primarily focuses on promoting institutional deliveries by offering incentives for women to give birth in health facilities. (C) Iron supplementation (Incorrect): Iron supplementation is a part of maternal care to prevent anemia during pregnancy, but it is not a direct component of JSY. While iron supplements are given during pregnancy, they are part of broader maternal health interventions, not specific to JSY. (D) Abortions (Incorrect): Abortions are not a focus of JSY. The Janani Suraksha Yojana is focused on promoting safe deliveries in health facilities and reducing maternal and neonatal deaths, not on facilitating abortions.

questions.text: NRHM was started in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 2005 The National Rural Health Mission (NRHM) was launched in 2005 by the Government of India to improve healthcare delivery in rural areas. The program aimed to address the health needs of rural populations, particularly in remote and underserved areas, by strengthening health infrastructure, improving service delivery, and increasing access to healthcare services. It was a key initiative to improve maternal and child health, reduce infant mortality rates (IMR) and maternal mortality rates (MMR), and promote health education. Incorrect Options: (B) 2006 (Incorrect): NRHM was launched in 2005, not in 2006. While there were continued developments and activities in subsequent years, the official launch year was 2005. (C) 2007 (Incorrect): The NRHM was not started in 2007. It was initiated in 2005, and 2007 is not the correct year for its launch. (D) 2009 (Incorrect): The NRHM was not started in 2009. It was launched earlier in 2005, and 2009 marked the period of further implementation and expansion of the program.

choices.text: Zero dose of OPV and BCG

questions.text: ASHA gets remuneration for all except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Recording birth weight ASHA (Accredited Social Health Activist) workers receive remuneration for certain health-related services that they provide within the community. However, recording birth weight is not one of the activities for which ASHA workers receive direct payment. ASHA is involved in tasks such as promoting institutional deliveries, ensuring zero dose of OPV (Oral Polio Vaccine) and BCG (Bacillus Calmette-Guerin) vaccinations, and facilitating birth registration, but the act of recording birth weight is typically part of routine health monitoring and is not directly linked to a payment under the ASHA remuneration system. Incorrect Options: (A) Institutional delivery (Correct): ASHA workers do receive remuneration for promoting institutional deliveries. They are incentivized to encourage pregnant women to give birth in health facilities, ensuring safer deliveries and better maternal and child health outcomes. (B) Zero dose of OPV and BCG (Correct): ASHAs are paid for ensuring the administration of the zero dose of OPV and BCG vaccines to newborns. This is an important task in the immunization program to protect infants from diseases like polio and tuberculosis. (D) Birth registration (Correct): ASHAs receive incentives for facilitating birth registration. This helps ensure that every child born is officially registered, making them eligible for social benefits and ensuring accurate demographic data.

choices.text: Free diet to mother during hospital stay
Free transport from home to hospital and back
Free treatment of child only up to 28 days

questions.text: All are true about JSSK except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Free treatment of child only up to 28 days Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram (JSSK) is a scheme under the National Health Mission (NHM) aimed at reducing out-of-pocket expenses for women and children. The scheme provides free healthcare services to pregnant women and newborns, particularly for those who are economically disadvantaged. One of the key components of JSSK is the free treatment for mothers and children, but free treatment for children under JSSK is not limited to only 28 days. Children are provided with free treatment up to 1 year of age in the event of sickness or complications, and not just up to 28 days. Incorrect Options: (A) Free diet to mother during hospital stay (Correct): JSSK ensures that mothers receive free diet during their hospital stay, which is aimed at providing better nutrition to support recovery and breastfeeding. This is part of the comprehensive support provided by JSSK during maternal care. (B) Free delivery (Correct): Under JSSK, delivery services (normal and cesarean) are provided free of charge, ensuring that women can give birth in a health facility without financial burden. This is a key feature of the scheme aimed at promoting institutional deliveries. (C) Free transport from home to hospital and back (Correct): JSSK covers free transport services for women in labor, from their homes to the hospital and back. This ensures that transportation costs do not act as a barrier to seeking essential maternity care.

choices.text: 60 mg of elemental iron and 500 micrograms of folic acid
100 mg of elemental iron and 500 micrograms of folic acid
120 mg of elemental iron and 750 micrograms of folic acid
200 mg of elemental iron and 1000 micrograms of folic acid

questions.text: Elemental iron & folic acid content of adult tablets supplied under national program:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 60 mg of elemental iron and 500 micrograms of folic acid Under the National Iron Plus Initiative (NIPI), the elemental iron and folic acid content in the adult tablets is 60 mg of elemental iron and 500 micrograms of folic acid. This formulation is recommended for the prevention and treatment of iron deficiency anemia among women of reproductive age, particularly in adults. The combination is aimed at improving hemoglobin levels and reducing the incidence of anemia. Incorrect Options: (B) 100 mg of elemental iron and 500 micrograms of folic acid (Incorrect): The recommended dose for adult women under the National Program is 60 mg of elemental iron, not 100 mg. Although 100 mg of iron may be used in certain therapeutic contexts, it is not the standard dose for prevention and general supplementation under the program. (C) 120 mg of elemental iron and 750 micrograms of folic acid (Incorrect): The standard formulation for adult tablets under the National Program contains 60 mg of elemental iron. The amount of 750 micrograms of folic acid is also higher than the required dosage under the typical national guidelines. (D) 200 mg of elemental iron and 1000 micrograms of folic acid (Incorrect): This dosage of 200 mg of elemental iron and 1000 micrograms of folic acid is too high for general supplementation purposes under national programs. Excessive iron supplementation can lead to side effects and is not routinely recommended unless medically indicated for severe anemia.

choices.text: 20 mg of elemental iron & 100 microgram of folic acid to 2-5 year old children weekly for an entire year
100 mg of elemental iron & 500 micrograms of folic acid to pregnant women biweekly for an entire year
60 mg of elemental iron & 500 micrograms of folic acid to pregnant women daily for an entire year
20 mg of elemental iron to all 2-5 year old children biweekly for an entire year

questions.text: Which of these is the correct dosing schedule according to the modified nation iron plus initiative program?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) 60 mg of elemental iron & 500 micrograms of folic acid to pregnant women daily for an entire year According to the Modified National Iron Plus Initiative (NIPI), the recommended dosing schedule for pregnant women is 60 mg of elemental iron and 500 micrograms of folic acid daily for an entire year. This schedule aims to address iron deficiency anemia during pregnancy, which is common, and also to meet the increased iron and folic acid needs during pregnancy. Incorrect Options: (A) 20 mg of elemental iron & 100 microgram of folic acid to 2-5 year old children weekly for an entire year (Incorrect): 20 mg of elemental iron and 100 micrograms of folic acid is not the correct dosage for weekly supplementation in children under the Modified NIPI. The typical dosage for 2-5 year-old children is usually iron at a lower dose than what is provided in the option. (B) 100 mg of elemental iron & 500 micrograms of folic acid to pregnant women biweekly for an entire year (Incorrect): The correct dosing schedule for pregnant women under NIPI is 60 mg of elemental iron and 500 micrograms of folic acid daily, not 100 mg biweekly. This biweekly dosage of 100 mg is higher than the recommended daily supplementation for pregnancy. (D) 20 mg of elemental iron to all 2-5 year old children biweekly for an entire year (Incorrect): Biweekly supplementation of 20 mg of elemental iron is typically used for certain populations (such as those at risk for anemia), but the Modified NIPI recommends daily supplementation for children, not biweekly, and typically uses higher iron doses when giving supplements to young children.

choices.text: Assisting & accompanying pregnant women to hospital for delivery
Primary screening for prevalence of non communicable disease
Assessing the success of national programme under ANM

questions.text: All of the following are duties of an ASHA worker except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Administering vaccines to children An Accredited Social Health Activist (ASHA) is a community health worker under the National Health Mission (NHM) who acts as a bridge between the healthcare system and the community. She plays a crucial role in maternal and child health, promoting immunization, and facilitating healthcare services, but she is not authorized to administer vaccines. Vaccination is done by trained healthcare professionals such as ANMs (Auxiliary Nurse Midwives) or medical officers. Incorrect Options: (A) Assisting & accompanying pregnant women to hospital for delivery (Correct Duty): ASHA workers are responsible for encouraging and assisting pregnant women in accessing institutional deliveries under Janani Suraksha Yojana (JSY). They accompany women to the hospital, ensure safe delivery, and help them avail government benefits. (B) Primary screening for prevalence of non-communicable disease (Correct Duty): ASHA workers conduct primary screening and community-level awareness campaigns for diseases like hypertension, diabetes, and cancer under programs like the National Program for Prevention and Control of Cancer, Diabetes, Cardiovascular Diseases, and Stroke (NPCDCS). They help in early detection and referral for non-communicable diseases. (D) Assessing the success of national programs under ANM (Correct Duty): ASHA workers assist the ANM (Auxiliary Nurse Midwife) in monitoring and evaluating the impact of national health programs such as Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn, Child, and Adolescent Health (RMNCH+A) and Immunization programs. They mobilize the community, track beneficiaries, and provide feedback on program implementation.

questions.text: Disease not under IDSP is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Herpes Zoster The Integrated Disease Surveillance Programme (IDSP) is a nationwide public health surveillance program in India that monitors the incidence of priority communicable diseases to detect early outbreaks and prevent epidemics. It focuses on epidemic-prone diseases, including vector-borne, waterborne, and airborne diseases. Incorrect Options: (A) Tuberculosis (TB) - Under IDSP TB is included in IDSP, but it is also primarily managed under the National TB Elimination Program (NTEP). Since TB is a major public health concern, its surveillance is crucial for tracking drug-resistant cases and controlling transmission. (B) Dengue - Under IDSP Dengue is a vector-borne disease that causes seasonal outbreaks in India, especially during monsoons. IDSP actively tracks Dengue cases as part of its early warning system to control outbreaks. (C) Cholera - Under IDSP Cholera is a waterborne disease that can cause rapid outbreaks due to poor sanitation and contaminated water. IDSP monitors cholera outbreaks to implement quick response measures, including water purification and public health advisories.

questions.text: In IDSP which of the following type of diagnosis is done by PHC medical officer?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Presumptive Diagnosis In the Integrated Disease Surveillance Programme (IDSP), different levels of healthcare facilities perform different types of diagnosis. The Primary Health Centre (PHC) Medical Officer is responsible for presumptive diagnosis, which means diagnosing a disease based on clinical symptoms and signs, without laboratory confirmation. Presumptive diagnosis is essential at the PHC level because many rural and remote healthcare centers lack advanced diagnostic facilities. The PHC Medical Officer initiates treatment based on clinical findings and, if needed, refers patients for further confirmatory testing at higher healthcare facilities. Incorrect Options: (A) Syndromic Diagnosis - Not Specific to PHC Medical Officers Syndromic diagnosis is a broader approach where diseases are identified based on a group of symptoms (syndromes) rather than a specific disease. It is used at the community level by frontline workers (e.g., ASHAs, ANMs) who do not have medical training but can identify cases needing medical attention. PHC doctors do not rely solely on syndromic diagnosis; they make presumptive diagnoses based on symptoms and clinical examination. (C) Confirmed Diagnosis - Done at Higher Centers Confirmed diagnosis requires laboratory testing or specialized investigations, which are usually done at district hospitals, medical colleges, or reference labs under IDSP. PHC-level facilities do not have advanced testing infrastructure for confirmatory diagnosis. (D) Active Surveillance - Conducted by Health Workers Active surveillance involves actively searching for cases in the community, especially during outbreaks. This is primarily done by health workers, epidemiologists, and surveillance officers, not by PHC medical officers, whose role is mainly clinical management and presumptive diagnosis.

questions.text: IMNCI includes all except :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Tuberculosis Integrated Management of Neonatal and Childhood Illness (IMNCI) is a strategy aimed at reducing infant and child mortality by addressing the most common causes of death in children under five years of age. It focuses on early diagnosis, treatment, and prevention of major childhood illnesses at the community and primary healthcare level. IMNCI includes three main components: - Improving case management skills of health workers - Strengthening the healthcare system - Enhancing family and community practices - The diseases covered under IMNCI are: - Respiratory infections (e.g., pneumonia) - Diarrheal diseases - Malaria (in endemic areas) - Measles - Malnutrition and its complications - Neonatal infections and birth-related conditions Incorrect Options: (A) Malaria - Included Malaria is a leading cause of febrile illness and mortality in children, especially in high-burden regions. IMNCI guidelines include fever management protocols to distinguish malaria from other causes of fever. (B) Respiratory Infection - Included Acute respiratory infections (ARIs), particularly pneumonia, are a major cause of death in children. IMNCI provides guidelines for diagnosing and treating pneumonia at the community level. (C) Diarrhea - Included Diarrheal diseases, especially acute watery diarrhea and dysentery, contribute significantly to childhood mortality due to dehydration. IMNCI promotes oral rehydration therapy (ORS), zinc supplementation, and proper nutrition for managing diarrhea.

choices.text: Sick neonates are preferred over sick older children
Treatment is aimed at more than one disease (Condition) at a time

questions.text: IMNCI differs from IMCI in all except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Sick new borne are given equal priority as the sick older children IMNCI/ Integrated Management of Neonatal and Childhood Illness • Developed by WHO + UNICEF • Colour coded: Pink/ Yellow/ Green • Objective: prevent deaths of child from preventable causes by standard case management • Modules: • Split into 2 parts • 0-2 months & 2 months to 5 years • Major highlights of Indian version of IMNCI is: • Inclusion of 0- 7 days age in the programme (IMCI globally) • Incorporating national guidelines on malaria, anaemia, vitamin A supplementation & immunization schedule • Training of health personnel begins with sick young infants up to 2 months of age • Skill based • Proportion of time for training devoted to sick young infant & sick child is almost equal

questions.text: Patient treated at home is allotted what color code according to IMNCI color coding?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Green The Integrated Management of Neonatal and Childhood Illness (IMNCI) color coding system is used to triage and classify the severity of illness in children under five years of age. It helps health workers quickly decide the appropriate treatment and management for sick children. IMNCI classifies cases into three color-coded categories: Pink (Severe illness - Urgent Referral to Hospital) Yellow (Moderate illness - Treatment at PHC/Health Facility) Green (Mild illness - Treatment at Home with Advice) Children classified under the green color category have mild illnesses and do not require hospitalization. These cases are treated at home with basic medications, fluids, nutrition, and supportive care. The caregiver is given instructions on home treatment and when to return if symptoms worsen. Incorrect Options: (A) Pink - Incorrect Pink is used for severe illness that requires urgent referral to a hospital. Conditions under this category include severe pneumonia, severe dehydration, severe malnutrition, convulsions, or danger signs (e.g., unconsciousness, inability to drink). These children must be sent to a higher healthcare facility immediately. (B) Red - Incorrect There is no "Red" color in the IMNCI classification system. Some emergency medical triage systems use red for life-threatening conditions, but IMNCI uses "Pink" instead. (D) Yellow - Incorrect Yellow is for moderate illness requiring treatment at a health facility but not urgent referral. Children in this category need oral antibiotics, oral rehydration, or specific treatment at a healthcare center before being sent home.

questions.text: IMNCI target age group is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Up to 5 years The Integrated Management of Neonatal and Childhood Illness (IMNCI) strategy is designed to reduce child mortality and morbidity by focusing on the most common childhood illnesses. It targets children from birth up to 5 years of age (0-59 months) because this age group is the most vulnerable to infections, malnutrition, and other preventable health conditions. IMNCI integrates preventive and curative care for newborns and children, addressing conditions such as: Neonatal health issues (e.g., infections, low birth weight, hypothermia) Respiratory infections (e.g., pneumonia) Diarrhea and dehydration Malaria and fever Malnutrition By targeting this specific age group, IMNCI helps in early identification, treatment, and referral of serious illnesses, ensuring improved child survival rates. Incorrect Options: (B) Up to 10 years - Incorrect IMNCI does not cover children beyond 5 years. Older children have different disease patterns and require different management strategies. (C) Up to 15 years - Incorrect Health programs for adolescents (10-19 years) are not included in IMNCI. Instead, they fall under programs like Rashtriya Kishor Swasthya Karyakram (RKSK). (D) Up to 20 years - Incorrect IMNCI focuses only on early childhood; adolescent and adult healthcare are managed separately.

questions.text: Under the national program for control of blindness in India medical colleges are classified as center’s:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Training Under the National Programme for Control of Blindness (NPCB) in India, medical colleges are classified as "Training Centers" because they play a crucial role in: Training Eye Care Professionals – Medical colleges provide specialized training to ophthalmologists, medical officers, and paramedical ophthalmic assistants (PMOAs) to enhance eye care services. Capacity Building – They help in developing human resources by training healthcare professionals at different levels. Research and Development – Many medical colleges conduct research on eye diseases, blindness prevention, and newer treatment modalities. Referral Services – These institutions serve as tertiary care centers, handling complex ophthalmic cases referred from lower healthcare facilities. Support for NPCB Goals – By training skilled personnel, medical colleges help in achieving the NPCB’s objective of reducing blindness prevalence. Incorrect Options: (A) Excellence – Incorrect The term "Centers of Excellence" is used for specialized institutes like AIIMS (All India Institute of Medical Sciences) and RP Centre for Ophthalmic Sciences, which focus on advanced research and super-specialty treatment. Medical colleges under NPCB are primarily training centers, not necessarily "centers of excellence." (C) Service – Incorrect While medical colleges do provide eye care services, their primary role under NPCB is training rather than direct service delivery like district hospitals or eye camps. (D) Vision – Incorrect The term "Vision Centers" generally refers to primary-level eye care centers that provide basic ophthalmic services in rural and underserved areas. Medical colleges function at a higher level, focusing on training and research rather than basic eye care.

choices.text: Cut off referral of a child is vision <6/9

questions.text: Under the school vision screening program all are true except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Age group screened is 5-10 years The School Vision Screening Program under the National Programme for Control of Blindness (NPCB) is aimed at early detection of refractive errors in school-going children to prevent avoidable blindness. However, the correct age group for screening is 10-15 years, not 5-10 years, making option (A) incorrect. Incorrect Options: (B) Screening is done by Teacher – Correct Teachers are trained to conduct preliminary vision screening for students. If a child is suspected to have a vision problem, they are referred to an ophthalmic assistant or specialist for further evaluation. (C) One teacher is for 150 students – Correct In this program, one trained teacher is responsible for screening approximately 150 students for vision defects. This helps ensure early detection and timely intervention. (D) Cut off referral of a child is vision <6/9 – Correct A child is referred to a specialist if visual acuity is less than 6/9 in either eye. This threshold ensures that mild visual impairment is detected early and corrective measures (like eyeglasses) are provided.

questions.text: ‘SAFE’ strategy for Trachoma, S stands for :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Surgery The SAFE strategy is a WHO-recommended approach for the elimination of trachoma, a leading cause of preventable blindness worldwide. S – Surgery: To correct trachomatous trichiasis (TT) and prevent blindness. A – Antibiotics: Mass drug administration of Azithromycin to treat active infection. F – Facial cleanliness: Encouraging personal hygiene to reduce transmission. E – Environmental improvement: Improving sanitation and access to clean water to break the cycle of infection. Incorrect Options: (B) Syringing – Incorrect Syringing is not a part of the SAFE strategy. It is mainly used in ear irrigation to remove wax or debris. (C) Streptomycin – Incorrect Streptomycin is not used in trachoma treatment. It is primarily used for tuberculosis and certain bacterial infections. (D) All of the above – Incorrect Since only "Surgery" is correct, choosing "All of the above" would be incorrect.

questions.text: In a town with population of 100,000 the number of slides examined is 5000. Out of these , 100 slides were positive for malaria . The API is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) 1 The Annual Parasite Incidence (API) is a measure used in malaria epidemiology to estimate the number of malaria cases in a given population. The formula for API is: API=(Number of Positive Slides/Population at Risk) x 1000 Given: • Number of Positive Slides = 100 • Population at Risk = 100,000 • Slides Examined = 5,000 (not directly needed for API calculation) Now, applying the formula: API=(100/10000) x 1000 = 1 Incorrect Options: (A) 2 – Incorrect • This would suggest 2 positive cases per 1,000 people, which does not match the correct calculation. (B) 5 – Incorrect • This is also incorrect, as it would imply a higher rate of malaria cases than what was calculated. (D) 0.5 – Incorrect • This value is lower than the actual calculated API, which is 1.

questions.text: Burden of malaria is best estimated by:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) API The Annual Parasite Incidence (API) is the most reliable and widely used measure for estimating the burden of malaria in a population. API reflects the number of confirmed malaria cases (usually confirmed by slide examination) per 1,000 population in a year. This measure helps to quantify the incidence of malaria and directly correlates with the disease burden in the community. Why API is the best: • It specifically measures the incidence of malaria in the population, making it the most accurate way to estimate the burden. • API helps in comparing the malaria burden over time or between different geographic regions. Formula for API: API=(Number of Confirmed Malaria Cases/Total Population at risk) x 1000 Incorrect Option (A) Mosquito Rate Mosquito rate refers to the density of mosquitoes in an area, which gives an idea of the vector population. However, it does not directly measure the disease burden. High mosquito density does not necessarily equate to high malaria transmission or high disease burden in humans. (C) Parasite The term "parasite" alone is vague. While the presence of the malaria parasite in individuals is essential, it does not directly estimate the burden of malaria. API is more specific and directly correlates the number of cases with the population size. (D) SPR (Slide Positivity Rate) Slide Positivity Rate (SPR) refers to the percentage of malaria positive slides out of the total number of slides examined. While it is useful for understanding the proportion of malaria cases detected, it does not fully capture the burden of the disease in the population, as it may miss many cases, especially in asymptomatic individuals

questions.text: Malaria eradication program based on use of insecticide aims to reduce lifespan of mosquito larval to less than
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) 6 days The malaria eradication program using insecticides aims to reduce the lifespan of mosquito larvae to less than 6 days. The reasoning behind this is that malaria transmission relies on the mosquito's ability to develop into an adult capable of spreading the malaria parasite. If the larvae do not survive long enough to reach adulthood, the transmission cycle is broken. By targeting and shortening the lifespan of larvae, insecticides prevent mosquitoes from becoming vectors, effectively reducing malaria transmission. Incorrect Options: (A) 1 day – Incorrect A lifespan of 1 day is too short for the mosquito larvae to develop into adult mosquitoes. While it is important to reduce the survival period, 1 day is not realistic for mosquito larvae to fully mature into adult mosquitoes capable of transmitting malaria. The target is to reduce their lifespan to a maximum of 6 days, not as short as 1 day. (B) 3 days – Incorrect 3 days is also too short for mosquito larvae to develop and survive into adults capable of transmission. While controlling the lifespan to 3 days would be beneficial, the key target is typically 6 days or less, which ensures that the mosquito larvae do not reach the adult stage in a time frame that would allow for the transmission of malaria. (D) 10 days – Incorrect While reducing the lifespan of larvae is crucial for stopping transmission, 10 days is too long. If mosquito larvae survive for 10 days, they can likely mature into adult mosquitoes that can carry and transmit the malaria parasite. The goal is to prevent their survival long enough to reach adulthood, and 6 days is the target for effective transmission control.

choices.text: ACT + single dose of Primaquine on day 2

questions.text: A pregnant women in 3rd trimester having fever was diagnosed as a case of falciparum malaria. Under NVBDC which drug is recommended?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) ACT only. In the case of a pregnant woman diagnosed with falciparum malaria in the third trimester, Artemisinin-based Combination Therapy (ACT) is the recommended treatment under the National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDC). ACT is the first-line treatment for uncomplicated falciparum malaria in pregnant women, particularly in the second and third trimesters. This regimen has shown to be both safe and effective in treating malaria during pregnancy. It targets the malaria parasite efficiently while minimizing potential harm to the fetus. Artemisinin-based therapies have been carefully studied and are known to be the most effective antimalarial agents for this condition. Incorrect options: B. ACT + single dose of Primaquine on day 2 Primaquine is not recommended for use during pregnancy, particularly in the first trimester and should be avoided in women who are pregnant. Although it is effective against the gametocyte stage of malaria, primaquine can cause hemolysis in individuals with G6PD deficiency and is contraindicated in pregnant women due to potential risks to the fetus. C. Quinine only While quinine is another option for the treatment of falciparum malaria during pregnancy, it is usually used in more severe cases or when ACT is not available. Quinine can be used with additional antimalarial drugs, but it is less preferred compared to ACT because ACT has shown to be more effective and better tolerated. D. Chloroquine Chloroquine is an older antimalarial drug and is generally not effective against Plasmodium falciparum in areas with widespread resistance. As falciparum malaria has developed resistance to chloroquine in many parts of the world, it is no longer recommended for treating falciparum malaria, particularly in regions with high resistance rates. Thus, ACT only is the most appropriate choice for treating falciparum malaria in a pregnant woman in the third trimester.

choices.text: Presumptive treatment with chloroquine is given
ACT is not given in falciparum
Primaquine is not given in falciparum
Primaquine contraindicated in infants and pregnant women

questions.text: According to revised malaria drug policy 2013, all are false except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Primaquine contraindicated in infants and pregnant women. According to the Revised Malaria Drug Policy (2013), primaquine is contraindicated in pregnant women and infants under the age of 6 months. This is because primaquine can cause hemolysis in individuals with G6PD deficiency, a condition that is relatively common and can lead to severe complications, particularly in newborns and infants. In pregnancy, primaquine can pose a risk to the fetus, and it is therefore not recommended during this period. Incorrect options: A. Presumptive treatment with chloroquine is given Presumptive treatment with chloroquine is not recommended under the revised policy for treating Plasmodium falciparum malaria, as chloroquine resistance is widespread. Chloroquine is typically recommended only for Plasmodium vivax in areas where resistance has not developed, but it is not used for presumptive treatment of falciparum malaria. B. ACT is not given in falciparum This is false. Artemisinin-based Combination Therapy (ACT) is the first-line treatment for Plasmodium falciparum malaria, particularly in areas where resistance to other antimalarial drugs like chloroquine is present. ACT is recommended for treating both uncomplicated and severe falciparum malaria under the revised drug policy. C. Primaquine is not given in falciparum This statement is incorrect because primaquine is used in the treatment of Plasmodium falciparum malaria only for the purpose of gametocyte clearance in certain cases, though it is not used for the treatment of the active stage of falciparum infection. However, primaquine is contraindicated in pregnant women and infants as mentioned in option D. Therefore, Primaquine is contraindicated in infants and pregnant women (option D) is the correct statement under the revised malaria drug policy.

questions.text: Plasmodium vivax malaria in pregnancy should be treated in pregnancy by:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Chloroquine. For Plasmodium vivax malaria during pregnancy, chloroquine is the preferred treatment. Chloroquine has been widely used for the treatment of Plasmodium vivax malaria and is considered safe during pregnancy, especially in the second and third trimesters. It effectively clears the parasite and is recommended under the revised malaria treatment guidelines. Incorrect options: B. Quinine Quinine is typically used for Plasmodium falciparum malaria or in cases of severe malaria, but it is not the first-line treatment for Plasmodium vivax. While quinine can be used when chloroquine is not available or in cases of chloroquine resistance, it is less commonly recommended for vivax malaria. C. Pyrimethamine Pyrimethamine is not a standard treatment for Plasmodium vivax malaria. It is sometimes used in combination with sulfadoxine in cases of chloroquine-resistant falciparum malaria, but it is not used for the treatment of Plasmodium vivax during pregnancy. D. Mefloquine Mefloquine is not the recommended treatment for Plasmodium vivax malaria in pregnancy. It is used for malaria prophylaxis and treatment in areas where resistance to other drugs exists, but it is avoided during pregnancy, particularly in the first trimester, due to potential risks to the fetus.

questions.text: Malaria surveillance should be done every:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Fortnightly. Malaria surveillance is typically done fortnightly (every two weeks) in endemic areas. This frequent monitoring helps in identifying new cases early, monitoring trends in malaria transmission, and ensuring timely responses to outbreaks. Regular surveillance also helps in evaluating the effectiveness of malaria control programs and interventions. Incorrect options: B. Yearly Yearly surveillance is too infrequent to effectively monitor and control malaria transmission. Malaria is a dynamic disease, and relying on yearly checks could allow outbreaks to go unnoticed for too long, delaying intervention and control measures. C. Monthly While monthly surveillance is better than yearly, it is still not frequent enough in high-risk areas, where cases can fluctuate rapidly. Fortnightly surveillance is more appropriate for timely interventions and better control of malaria transmission. D. Weekly Although weekly surveillance could be ideal in some high-risk settings, fortnightly surveillance is generally sufficient to monitor the situation effectively without overwhelming resources. Weekly checks may be unnecessary and resource-intensive in areas where transmission is stable and malaria incidence is relatively low.

questions.text: Blood smear must be made at night for which of the following conditions:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Filaria. A blood smear for filaria must be made at night because the adult worms of Wuchereria bancrofti and Brugia malayi, the parasites responsible for filariasis, release their microfilariae (larval stage) into the bloodstream primarily at night. This phenomenon is known as nocturnal periodicity. For accurate diagnosis, blood smears should be taken between 10 PM and 2 AM, as this is when the microfilariae are most abundant in the peripheral circulation. Incorrect options: A. Malaria Malaria parasites, including Plasmodium falciparum, vivax, malariae, and ovale, circulate in the blood throughout the day, making it unnecessary to specifically collect blood at night. Blood smears for malaria can be done at any time. C. Leprosy Leprosy is caused by Mycobacterium leprae, which does not require blood smears for diagnosis. Diagnosis is usually based on clinical features, skin biopsy, and smear from lesions. A blood smear is not typically used for diagnosing leprosy, and the time of day does not affect the test. D. Onchocerciasis Onchocerciasis, caused by Onchocerca volvulus, also does not require blood smears at night. The microfilariae of Onchocerca are typically found in the skin and are diagnosed by skin snips rather than blood smears.

questions.text: STEPS done for surveillance of:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Risk factors of NCD. Surveillance for risk factors of non-communicable diseases (NCDs) involves monitoring and identifying factors that increase the likelihood of developing NCDs, such as high blood pressure, high cholesterol, obesity, physical inactivity, smoking, and poor diet. Surveillance of these risk factors allows for early identification of individuals at higher risk, enabling public health programs to intervene and promote healthier lifestyles to prevent the onset of NCDs. Incorrect options: B. Incidence of NCD While surveillance of the incidence (new cases) of NCDs is important for understanding the burden of disease, it is not typically the first step in surveillance. Monitoring risk factors is usually a proactive approach that helps prevent the incidence of NCDs, while incidence surveillance focuses more on tracking the occurrence of the diseases themselves. C. Evaluation of treatment of NCD Evaluating the treatment of NCDs involves assessing how effectively the existing treatment protocols are working, which is part of health program evaluation rather than initial surveillance. Treatment evaluation focuses on patient outcomes and treatment adherence, which is a step that occurs after identifying and diagnosing the condition, not during surveillance. D. Mortality from NCD Surveillance of mortality from NCDs focuses on tracking the number of deaths attributed to these diseases, which provides valuable epidemiological data. However, monitoring risk factors (option A) is typically more proactive and preventive, aiming to reduce the burden of NCDs before they lead to mortality.

questions.text: ICDS is under which ministry :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Women & Child Development. The Integrated Child Development Services (ICDS) scheme is a flagship program under the Ministry of Women and Child Development (MWCD). It focuses on improving the nutritional and health status of children, pregnant women, and lactating mothers. The program provides a range of services, including supplementary nutrition, immunization, health check-ups, pre-school education, and referral services, all aimed at the holistic development of children under the age of 6 and their mothers. Incorrect options: A. Health & Family Welfare Although the Ministry of Health & Family Welfare plays a crucial role in healthcare and maternal/child health, ICDS specifically falls under the Ministry of Women and Child Development, which is more focused on social welfare and the holistic development of children and women. C. Home Affairs The Ministry of Home Affairs is primarily concerned with internal security, law and order, and national policies related to governance. It does not oversee social welfare programs like ICDS. D. Labour The Ministry of Labour is responsible for labor laws, employment policies, and welfare of workers, but it does not manage the ICDS program, which is centered around child and maternal health. Thus, the Ministry of Women and Child Development (option B) is the correct answer for overseeing ICDS.

questions.text: ICDS was launched in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) 1975. The Integrated Child Development Services (ICDS) program was launched in 1975 by the Government of India. It was introduced with the aim of improving the nutritional and health status of children, pregnant women, and lactating mothers, and also to provide early childhood education. ICDS was a pioneering initiative to address the multi-dimensional aspects of child development and has since been expanded and adapted across the country. Incorrect options: A. 1955 1955 is too early for the launch of ICDS. At that time, other health and welfare programs were in place, but ICDS was not yet introduced. B. 1968 While India was focusing on various social welfare programs in the 1960s, the ICDS program was officially launched in 1975, not in 1968. D. 2005 2005 is much later than the actual launch of ICDS, which was in 1975. By 2005, the program had already been running for several decades and had seen significant expansion.

choices.text: Prevalence of goiter among school children

questions.text: The best indicator for monitoring the impact of iodine deficiency disorders control programme is :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Urinary iodine levels. Urinary iodine levels are considered the best indicator for monitoring the impact of the iodine deficiency disorders (IDD) control program. This is because iodine is primarily excreted through urine, and its concentration in urine reflects recent dietary intake of iodine. A median urinary iodine level of at least 100 micrograms per liter in a population is considered an indicator of sufficient iodine intake and effective iodine deficiency control. This measure is widely used to assess the iodine status of a population and the success of the iodine supplementation program. Incorrect options: A. Prevalence of goiter among school children While the prevalence of goiter among school children is a commonly used indicator for assessing iodine deficiency, it is not the best indicator of iodine deficiency control. Goiter is a late manifestation of iodine deficiency, and by the time goiter appears, iodine deficiency may already be a long-standing issue. Urinary iodine levels provide a more immediate and accurate reflection of iodine status. C. Neonatal hypothyroidism Neonatal hypothyroidism can result from iodine deficiency, but it is a less direct and less sensitive measure compared to urinary iodine levels. It is a more severe outcome and may not be seen as early as changes in urinary iodine levels, making it less effective for routine monitoring. D. Iodine level in soil While iodine levels in soil can affect the iodine content of local food sources, it is not a reliable indicator of the effectiveness of an iodine deficiency control program. Iodine status is better reflected by measures of intake and excretion (like urinary iodine) than by iodine levels in the soil, which can vary widely based on geographic and environmental factors.

questions.text: FSSAI comes under
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) MOHFW (Ministry of Health and Family Welfare). The Food Safety and Standards Authority of India (FSSAI) is an autonomous body established under the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare (MOHFW). FSSAI is responsible for regulating and supervising food safety in India. It develops standards for food products, ensures their compliance, and promotes awareness regarding food safety and hygiene among consumers and food businesses. Incorrect options: A. Ministry of Consumer Affairs Although the Ministry of Consumer Affairs deals with consumer protection, FSSAI is primarily under the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare. The Ministry of Consumer Affairs focuses more on consumer rights, grievances, and fair trade practices, rather than food safety regulations. B. Ministry of Agriculture The Ministry of Agriculture focuses on farming, crop production, and agricultural policies. While agriculture can impact food safety, FSSAI specifically deals with food standards and safety regulations, which is under the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare. D. Ministry of Rural Development The Ministry of Rural Development works on policies related to rural areas and their development, including employment, infrastructure, and poverty alleviation. It does not oversee food safety regulations, which falls under MOHFW through FSSAI.

questions.text: ‘Nikshay’ is used for tracking of
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) TB. Nikshay is an online platform developed by the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare (MOHFW) for the tracking and monitoring of tuberculosis (TB) patients in India. It is part of the National Tuberculosis Elimination Program (NTEP) and is used to record and track TB cases, monitor treatment progress, and ensure timely and effective intervention. The platform helps in improving the surveillance, reporting, and management of TB cases in the country. Incorrect options: A. High risk newborns There is no specific program called "Nikshay" for tracking high-risk newborns. Newborn care is typically managed through other healthcare initiatives like RCH (Reproductive and Child Health) and IMNCI (Integrated Management of Neonatal and Childhood Illness). B. Malaria While malaria tracking is vital for public health, Nikshay is not used for malaria. Malaria surveillance in India is typically handled under the National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP). D. High risk pregnancy High-risk pregnancies are monitored under maternal and child health programs such as RCH and Janani Suraksha Yojana (JSY), but not through the Nikshay platform.

choices.text: Is a type of insurance scheme

questions.text: Ayushman Bharat all are true except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Entitled for 30,000 rupees/family. Ayushman Bharat, specifically the Pradhan Mantri Jan Arogya Yojana (PMJAY), is a health insurance scheme aimed at providing financial protection to economically vulnerable populations. It offers coverage of up to 5 lakh rupees per family per year for secondary and tertiary care hospitalization. The amount mentioned in option B (30,000 rupees) is incorrect because the coverage is much higher. Incorrect Options: A. Applicable for BPL only Ayushman Bharat primarily targets the economically vulnerable population, which includes both Below Poverty Line (BPL) families and other identified groups.
